label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, January 20, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, advising her on how to proceed in her work for the government, describing a new game, and recounting the events of a party he and Morris attended at the Officer’s Club.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, advising her on how to proceed in her work for the government, describing a new game, and recounting the events of a party he and Morris attended at the Officer’s Club.

metadata.label: Access Note

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
52
January 20,1943
Gertie Darling,
Today I received everything in the world
from you. A wonderful shaving set with soap, afterlotion,
andpo[w]der in a most attractive box. A book by fressie Oeschener
and an V mail letter of January 11,. Youasked me to let
youknow whether the V mail was fast er than your letter 55.
Letter 55 beat the V mail by four days. I think you are
under some misunderstanding about the air mail as far as
I know we are still sending and receiving air mail. I know
that everyones experience with V mail is that it si anywhere
from four to ten days latter than [air] mail.
I am so sorry to he r that your boss is going
across. Surely you should be able to work something with
him that would get you across also so that you may share in
the excitement of what is happening in Europe. Is he taking
anyone with him. You know asking never hurt and it might
mean the difference between going and staying in the States.
Your letter 55 sounds as if you are really fed
up with the whole business and want to do something else.
It is so hard for me to advise youfrom hear. I know
sometimes when everything looks blackest one gets the breaks.
If you stop just short of the line you can never win. Against
that is the fact that you can be stuck in a job that will
drive you nuts. Without knowing the facts and seeing what your
chances are in something else I am unable to tell youwhat
to do. Certainlyif you start in a new project you will have
the same number of dreary months to work up to a position
equallying your present one. At times I think I will go nuts
here doing the same thing everyday. Ordering Paper clips,
stapling papers, hearing ever ones complaints and telling
them I cannot recomment them for premotion. There is no future
in it, but then we must not expect a fut[u]re in the navy or in
strategic services because neither of us have any intention of
remaining in this type of work. All we can do is try and
do our present jobs with the greatest efficeincy possible and
thus help the war effort. Some people arelucky as hell ,they
are travelling all over the world and seeing interesting
people , but you must remember we had twelve years of a life
that was almost mythical. Travel, shooting, tennis in palm
beach, swimming on the Riviera etc. and there must be a certain
amount of bad with the good that we will accept without to
much compalaining. There is another point about your 
remaining where you are which you may or may not consider
important, that is Bo. We have seen what Landine has grown up
to be. Maybe she was destined to be that way, but I do believe
[End Page 1]
that the lonely hotel life of nurses , boarding houses,
and never seeing her parents had a profund influence on
her life. You may not think that Bobo is affected by what you
say and do, but I am certain that she is, and the fact that
she has a mother with her m kes an enormous difference . You
have always spoken to me of how wonderful you r life was with
your mother and how much she meant to you, and I feel that
Bo could or could not feel the same way latter in life
depending on whether she is with her mother or not. Please do
not feel that this is a suggestion that you should stay
with the children, because it is not. It is simply an idea
that may be basen on an entirely wrong premise and as a result
worthless.
I know a Warren Delano that is in stragegic
services out here. He comes into our office everyone once
in a while to see the captain and seems to be able to le d
a very nice beach life besides as he is as brown as a berry
and is always at the outrigger club when we go there. They
all play some kind of a game with a basketball. Two men to a
side and you knock the ball over a very high net. The court is
sand which makes the running seem very difficult. The men
on one side knock it in the air between themselves until they
jockey into positions where they think they are able to hit [it]
over the net so that their opponents cannot prevent it from
touching the ground. I am certain that it is a game for the
young as it takes a great deal of running in the heavy sand and
the men are covered with perspiration.
Last night we went to a dinner and a cocktail
party and then danced at the officers club in Hickham field.
You wouldhave died, had you seen us. Two old men asked out by
two girls of about eighteen. We went to their fathers house for
coctails, a colonel in the army. There were lots of generals
there with a fair sprinkling of colonels and majors. I
consumed lots of bourbon, that is all that is drunk out here,
why I don't know except they say that whenthe misssionaries first
came they sold the Hawaiians bourbon xxx because it was the ch
cheapest liker to xxxx and therefor the greatest profit was
realized. The colonel was a little shaken when he saw Morrises
bald head and my graying hair[,]but was very nice. After
cocktails we went to the Army club for dinner andthere the
piece de resistance was Artie Shaw and his orchestra. Of all
the lousy music that is the worst. People have sp[o]iled him and
his men so that they never have more than on instrument playing
at a time, probably under the impression that is jazz or swing
or something. My seat at the table confirmed my impression
that the colonel had recognized my age. I was sitting at the
end of a long horseshoe table . On either side of me were men
and beyoned them for two seats were more men so that the nearest
women,who I did not know,was three seats away. I danced once
and then the music st[o]ped at nine and the party was over.
A general asked us to come back to his house for drinks so we
went there and had a big time pouring down bourbon and soda
[End Page 2]
until 9:45 when we returned to our home as you are not allowed
on the streets xxxxx after ten in a car. It use to be eight,
but they now let us stay until ten which is very liberal indeed.
Morris and I felt very badly indeed this morning and have
sworn no more of this foolishness for us. Back to our life
of in bed at seven with time or the readers digest and to hell
with the young girls, their papas and the drunken old generals.
It is very cold here and has been for the past
week. Thatis cold in comparison with what it usually is.
We wear our kaki coats and overcoats in the morning, but it
is quite warm by noon and one prespires in a shirt in the sun.
However no one is one the beach in the afternoon, Hawaiins
think[scratched through] that swimm ming should only be done from June to Septe-
mber. I have not surfXXed since that wonderful sunday two weeks
ago as there have not been any waves and besides it is really
to cold in the evening to sit on a board with t he wind blowing
on ones back .
Goodbye sweetheart, all my love goes with
t is letter.
Sidney J. Legendre
PS just spoke to the post office and they said all our letters
from here go airmail, but they do not know what the situation
is in the states whetehr your letters come out air mail
or not. Ring the post office up and find out definitley.
[End Page 3]
